DataElement.preferredName: Other Ductal Breast Carcinoma in Situ Histology Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text description of a ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) histologic type of 'other'.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue.:Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts.  There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane.  Currently, DCIS is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis.  The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS. --2002

Concepts.definition: Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.

A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

Property.preferredDefinition: The process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms.

Concepts.definition: The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredName: Other Ductal Breast Carcinoma in Situ Histology Text
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Text description of 'other' ductal carcinoma in situ histologic type.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Other Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ Histology Text
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Not otherwise specified.:Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, DCIS is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS. --2002:The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.:Text; the words of something written.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

DataElement.changeDescription: Curated to create I-SPY data collection forms.
